repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Suralaya Thermal Power Project
            and Sumatera and Kalimantan Power Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit rates the Suralaya Thermal
            Power (STP) Project outcome as moderately satisfactory, with
            unlikely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts, in contrast to the Implementation
            Completion Report (ICR) ratings of unsatisfactory outcomes,
            and substantial institutional development impacts.
            Conversely, it concurs with the ICR ratings of the Sumatera
            and Kalimantan Power (SKP) Project of unsatisfactory
            outcome, and unlikely sustainability, but upgrades
            institutional development impacts from modest to
            substantial. The findings of the Thematic Overview suggest
            that the radically changed circumstances in the Indonesian
            power sector, are conducive to the Bank's continuing
            reluctance to support new generation projects, which may
            have to be reconsidered, and alternative ways of structuring
            mixed public-private generation projects need to be
            explored. Lessons drawn from the performance assessment of
            these two projects include: 1) meticulous coal quality
            monitoring is essential for a plant where minor differences
            in coal characteristics can have a significant impact on
            boiler efficiency, with substantial financial consequences;
            2) a secure long-term supply contract for coal with the
            optimal characteristics for the Suralaya boilers may justify
            the payment of a price premium, because of the financial
            consequences of a poorer heat rate, plant unavailability due
            to more frequent outages, and increased maintenance costs;
            3) an automatic tariff adjustment mechanism can only operate
            satisfactorily under relatively stable macroeconomic
            conditions: variations in the exchange rate, fuel prices,
            and inflation, cannot be dealt with, through a technical
            formula that is de-linked from socio-political
            considerations; and, 4) project objectives should be
            directly linked to project components. Furthermore, compared
            to Specific Investment Loans, an Adaptable Program Loan
            would appear to be a more appropriate lending instrument for
            the pursuit of sector reforms that require consensus
            building, and are particularly suitable instruments in
            countries where the Bank has a regular sequence of lending
            operations in the same sector.

2420965.trustfund:
TF034857-INDONESIA - SUMATERA I POWER
            WILAYAHS III AND IV,TF034917-INDONESIA - POWER DISTRIBUTION
            IN JAVA,TF026405-SECONDMENT OF A DANISH SOCIOLOGIST,TF028184-REG. SECONDMENT ANTHROPOLOGIST (ASTHR)

abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings gave mixed results,
            for although its outcome is unsatisfactory, and
            sustainability is unlikely, substantial institutional
            development impacts were assessed, in view of greater
            management decentralization, and the creation of more
            autonomous business units. In addition, the performances of
            both the Bank, and Borrower were rated as satisfactory,
            given the strong, and continuous dialogue with the
            Government, who focused on much more than the agreed project
            objectives, identifying sector issues discussed with the
            State Electricity Corporation. Lessons reinforce the need
            for full Government commitments, to enhance coordination
            among suppliers, contractors, consultants, and donors, and
            achieve appropriate management capacity. Conversely, the
            successful Bank responsiveness to the financial crisis,
            through an increase of loan disbursement percentages for
            local expenditures, was instrumental in avoiding potential
            delays due to shortage of counterpart funds. But, realistic,
            and sound project cost estimates would have certainly
            avoided the large amounts of loan cancellations.
            Furthermore, the high cost of the Independent Power Producer
            to meet its financial objective, indicate the need for risk
            analysis, and, the use of a "rate of return on revalued
            assets" covenant to measure financial performance, is
            not appropriate for an entity with a very large investment program.

5079276.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
5079276.theme: Infrastructure services for private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The project includes: (1) the
            construction of three coal-fired units each at Suralaya,
            including associated works and a transmission line from
            Cilegon to Cibinong, with associated substations; (2)
            consulting services for engineering, design and construction
            supervision of the units; (3) a feasibility study for a high
            voltage submarine cable link between Java and Sumatra; (4)
            engineering and design of a thermal power plant at
            Banjarmasin in South Kalimantan; (5) consulting services for
            institutional development; and (6) training of the State
            Electricity Corporation staff in public utilities practices.
